segments.text: Okay, what are the good parts of House Bill 72?
Well, we've hit on a number of them.
The increase in teacher salaries was essential.
I mean, the salary before the bill was $11,100, and 70% of the districts we had ever studied showed that 70% of the districts 40 years ago did not add more than 10% to that base.
Well, in terms of attracting and keeping big people, it was not competitive.
The 15-2 isn't really competitive yet.

I mean, with the bonuses in the career ladder, it could be, but those are going to have to be increased because if you compare the salaries of people who have graduated from Texas A&M with a four-year degree, right, in other fields such as business and engineering and these other fields, the 15-2 isn't competitive.
You're going to have to go beyond that.

I'd like to see us move more toward a career ladder with a 12-month employment for some teachers where they can work with tutoring programs in the summer, special programs for the gifted, like the program they have up in Garland.
They have a program called Academic Coaches where they work in the summer.
And instead of just having them coach, like the coaches are hired to coach the football in the summer, these people are hired to coach kids who are gifted kids or
kids with special problems, and move toward a system where we have third and fourth level career ladder teachers on a 10-month assignment, a 12-month assignment.

Not necessarily teaching in regular class, but running training programs for other teachers in the summer, setting up programs where you can have the beginning teachers of the previous year come back in that summer for extra help from moving into the second year, not treat the beginners as if they're experienced people,
Every other profession has an induction program for beginning teachers.
And they have a mentor working with them through their first year of teaching.
And then they work with them in their second year.
And those are the kinds of things that I think are going to be essential.
So the salary thing and the structure for career ladders, if we can work it out, would be one of the best things to ever happen.
The scholarship programs have to be expanded.
The research and development
component that's in there, the uses of the new technology.
See, part of the solution to the teacher shortage is not to try to keep doing what we're doing.
It's to use the talent you've got better in a differentiating way.
And have some of the models, like talk to us.
We have the master teacher, the two regular teachers, and two interns.
Take 100 students.

And you match your five people, one with a math background, one with a science background, one with an English background, one with a social studies background, and a backup person to work with the computers and the technology, working as a team with those 100 students.
And then you utilize the talents of the people in different ways with those 100 students.
Instead of organizing the school around each 50-minute period, we've done 50 minutes of math, 50 minutes of media,
50 minutes in science, 50 minutes in the gym, 50 minutes in foreign language.
I mean, it's boring.
Just more of that isn't going to improve the schools.
It may just compound the boredom.

You've got to think about having sometimes when students work in independent study activities with instructional programs and computers, sometimes when they're in small groups, sometimes when they're in large groups.

And then instead of having this outstanding physics teacher teaching five periods a day, you might use that person to teach three periods and then have the students work in independent study areas two days a week with the interns.
And use that teacher, that outstanding teacher, much more wisely.
That's the only way we're going to solve the shortage.
Now, the programs in terms of smaller class sizes, I think they're terrific.
I think that Texas could really be a leader in the nation if they implemented that.
I'm worried about that because a lot of it seems to be pulling back from that.
I think the programs for four-year-olds, especially in disadvantaged areas where you have to have a lot of mothers and fathers, both parents working,
We discovered that 28% of the kids in the school are coming single-parent homes.
69% come from homes where both parents work.
So if you could have a program where each of these four-year-olds would get some help in starting off on the right foot, regardless of their background, if you could help those kids stop
of learning, reading, writing, and spelling in those first three days.
That, I think, is one of the major aspects of this bill.
The payoff, unless you pay not be able to see until 12, 15 years from now, it's only important to stick with those requirements.
There are a lot of other good aspects of the bill.
I think the requirement in terms of
the accreditation where they would be evaluating these school districts and holding them to these standards, if they can set that up.
And I would hope they would look when they go into these school districts to make sure they're not hiring unqualified teachers.
One of the real scandals in this state and states around the country is the number of people that are hiring on emergency permits.
Just putting a warm body in a class to hold the class.
There are 5,892 emergency permits given in Texas two years ago.
I don't have last year's data.
I'm sure it's gone up.
And then there's a lot of school districts that are allowing teachers to teach out of their field if they've been prepared.
With the math shortage, some districts have taken the elementary teachers who've had some courses in math and making them secondary education math teachers.
Well, that's not right.
That's not going to improve.

See, the requirement now that there be another year of math for every high school student will just be a hoax perpetuated in the public by the legislature if we can't get more and better math teachers.
We've got a state where over half the teachers who were hired two years ago to teach math were unqualified teachers.
Now requiring another year of math for every high school student, which will triple the need for math teachers at a time when only half the people teaching math
are unqualified to teach it.
So you don't just improve quality by making regulations or laws.
It takes an incentive system to get competitive salaries to get these outstanding math students to go into teaching rather than going to work for IBM.
And they're not going to be attracted to teaching unless you give them good salaries and the conditions in the workplace
where they can feel like they're making a major contribution.
I personally believe that there are a lot of outstanding people out there who would like to get into teaching if we can make it an exciting work setting.
We've got a situation here at A&M where we have 264 majors in Mathematics Education and 329 in Science Education.
We prepare more math and science people than any university in the nation.
But if these people

and not get good salaries and good support as teacher scholars who are treated as people who are responsible for the intellectual development of children, not babysitters or policemen in study halls, they're going to leave teaching.
Unless you can improve the condition of the workplace and improve the reward system.
Now they will stick with it because you've got to love kids and love teachers
in order to sustain a profession, you know, stay in the profession.

But you can't expect people to stay in a profession where they can't make enough money to send their own kids out to college, where they spend their whole life preparing other people's kids for college.
And so these are some of the things in the bill that are yet to be implemented that I think should make a real difference.
Governor Mark White is planning to have Texas colleges
universities reform what are necessary reforms for higher education we got another do we have another couple of hours you know all of the there's a new book out by Ernest Boyer
on policy issues in higher education.
Anyway, what he does, he talks about the five contradictions in higher education.
You've got a situation where the professors
These are five areas we have to deal with.
The first area is we've got to get the expectations of the professors tuned in with the students that they're teaching.
It's very hard to get professors to focus on students and what the students do.
And when they do, they never satisfy those students.
better students.
They want the high achievers in high SAT scores.
And there's a lot of blame placed as students come to the colleges unprepared and that kind of thing.
So one of the real problems is we have to get the professors committed to teaching the students that they end up with.
And if it's a community college, we don't expect students to
have the abilities that the people that hire them have.
And what I think we need more than anything else right now is a student orientation of the product and the commitment to that as a major mission of the university.
And research is important.
But the primary mission of the university is to educate the students .
And that has to be put back and forth.
The other area, another area, is the curriculum itself.
The whole issue of how much career and vocational preparation and how much general education.
It was the same issue as the select committee talked about.
What's the place of vocational education and seminary education?
If you extend that,
to higher education.
How much of it should be career oriented to a career?
And there are a lot of debates now that the best preparation for most careers should probably be a good liberal education for people.
It should be a good core curriculum for everybody.
The engineers who go through four years of preparation without any humanities courses are not prepared, either for engineering or for the world.
And I think you can make a case for that myself.
But that's for the day.
We need to define what the core curriculum should be in 1985 to prepare people for living out their lives in the 20th century.
And we need to be clear on how much time is needed in the curriculum to be devoted to that.

And now it's just a matter of saying everybody ought to take two courses of math, two courses of history, two courses of English, two courses of a foreign language, and then quote, then literally educate them.
I think a lot of it has to do with how it's taught also.
If you're just in a class being taught by a graduate assistant and 200 students, you know, you're not learning too much about inquiry.
If you're just sitting there listening to his lecture, he doesn't even want to be there.
He's just making his graduate assistantship money.
You know, we really need to get some of these full professors started to teach all these other courses again.
Like how to make a real commitment to teach the main curriculum, et cetera.
The whole area of student affairs in higher education is similar, isn't it?
What is the role of student affairs in a university?
Now here we have over 500 books.
I think this would be a completely different place without the student affairs program.
It has a major impact on intellectual refinement, as well as the social environment of people of every age that people are acting like.
I talked to Susan Ellis one time about this, and she said,
He told me that the thing that made the most difference in his life when he was at A&M was the way he encouraged the government.
He got interested in international relations.
He got interested in politics.
He got interested in managing the business.
He went to hire the business.
But it was an out-of-class activity in the environment of student involvement in this kind of thing.
It gave him that.
But we need to look at these kinds of things in addition to looking at the curriculum.

There's going to be a lot of interest from the private government and the state on how you can use education as an instrument for economic development and how you can use it to teach people to be ready for the technological age.
Texas economy is dependent on oil.
The government's duty in terms of the mind of the Texas student is the new oil.
The new oil of Texas.
And that's going to solve the state's problems with the economy.
Well, another area is to get Texas beyond itself.
to the international activities.
Right now, we're all neighbors, and then something happens in Ireland and Italy and, you know, some down in Mexico and other stuff.
We're all part of it.
So you've got to start acting like we're citizens of the world.
you know, as soon as there's a call at a station and get out of our current, you know, our attitudes about who we are and where we want to relate to individually.
And every, and this shouldn't just be for colleges, students ought to be getting this in the schools.
There ought to be a global approach to study in all of the schools in this state.
We've got a long way to go in that, I think, in terms of the kind of education that we provide.
This out-of-state student increase in tuition and things like that can be without a lack of sensitivity in some respects to the need.
The value for Texas students in having an international student body
that we shouldn't be saying, let's take them and help them out.
We should be saying, let's take them because they're essential to having a world, a university that's world-oriented.
They add as much to our environment as we give to them.
And that attitude, I think, is going to have to be looked at, particularly looking beyond
Texas and what they want this particular year, but this university should become.
Those are just a few of the things.
I think we need to take a look at articulation between the high schools, the community colleges, and the university.
Much closer working together.
I think we need to take a look at the collaboration and cooperation within systems
and a cross-system in the state, I think we could do much more within our own system as we work between Prairie View and this campus.
And it's only 45 minutes away.
We ought to be having a lot more exchange programs between students, a lot more exchange programs between faculty.
We're even on different calendars.
We're not even on the same calendar.
And then when we try to do exchanges, you know, swap faculty.
Well, if a person goes down there and teaches, he has a different calendar for the course he's teaching than we have here.
So it makes it very hard.
If we were just on the same calendar, we could swap easily.
I mean, instead of a person teaching the sociology course down at Fairview, and we could teach it up here.
Same course, same, you know, level.
just swap and teach one place or another each semester.
We could do a lot more of that.
We could enhance the environment of both campuses.
But we don't.
We're only 45 minutes away.
We can go to Europe and London and have comparative education programs in London.
We have programs only in Japan.
But it seems to be harder to go down here in a prairie
45 minutes a week.
I bet more faculty members have been to foreign countries than have been down to Paris.
Okay.
What are the advantages and disadvantages of reforming higher education?
I don't think there are any disadvantages.
I think that there are many aspects of almost any organization
to make it better.
And I don't know of any organization that couldn't be better.
The key is to decide what needs changing and to make sure that change is better than what existed.
There's a wonderful saying that I've learned since I've been here in Texas.
Don't fix it until it's broke.
There are enough things that are broke to be changed.
that we can work on without following up the things that are going well.
And it takes some analysis to make sure that we need to spend that time on what needs changing and what's possible to change.
You shouldn't spend a whole lot of time on things that can't be changed.
But things that can be changed and ought to be changed, we ought to be working on.
And I think that that will take
you know, some real study.
And we ought to set up some evaluation process to make sure we get feedback on whether we're achieving what we set out to achieve.
And that has to be built into the initial plan as we go about doing it.
And like any kind of reform, you know, change, we can move either backwards or forwards with a change.
all changes didn't necessarily bring improvement.
So we have to say that we're going to set up and accomplish something and set up a system to evaluate how does the quality of Texas public education compare with other states?
Texas has some speculative problems.
And one of the worst things we do, and the state and the federal government recently did this, is to take these SAT scores in one state and compare them with another.
The first thing that's wrong with that, if you look at this first, is that
In some states, only 5% or 6% of the students take the test.
But in Texas, 32% of the students take the test.
69% in Connecticut take it.
3% in North Dakota.
So that kind of data doesn't mean anything.
So when we do comparisons, we have to be careful.
But what we need to do is look at, instead of saying, how does it compare, we ought to be saying, how well are we doing in improving what exists in Texas?
Now, Texas has a situation where 37% of the students in the school are from Hispanic backgrounds.
Texas and California.
California would probably be the first state where what was the minority would become the majority.
Texas would probably be second.
So we have a special problem in having a number of children that speak English as a second language.
We need to say, how are we doing at solving that problem so all of these kids can have equal access to educational opportunity in the state
as it moves, where this population that it has is going to be able to meet the needs of the year 2000.
Everybody has a piece of the action here to deal with this problem.
Education is not something that just schools should be concerned about.
This study that I just finished working on with the Committee for Economic Development, Investing in Our Children,
business in the school.
Industry and business have a role to play in this, and the higher ed institutions have a role to play in improving the public education.
So instead of spending our time saying, how do we compare with somebody else using these crazy tests, which we don't have the same populations we're comparing
We should be systematically identifying what it is we're trying to achieve, and then ask ourselves, how well are we doing in it?
And I believe that if you look at the effort that Texas is making as a criterion for how we're doing, we could get A's for that.
I've never been in a state where there's more commitment to doing something about improving education.
Now, beating up on each other about how bad things are won't do it.
I mean, that's a waste of energy.
We need to say, what are we doing well?
And there are a lot of things we're doing well.
You know, I think the Barling-Williams programs in Texas are models for the rest of the nation.
We ought to be very proud of them.
And we can show you and show in certain districts where there have been tremendous strides made.
There are outstanding schools in the state that could be used as lighthouse schools.
If you look at the kind of programs in Houston School District in terms of the magnet schools, Dallas has some outstanding programs going on there.
There are school districts and rural schools all over the state that have some exciting things going on.
We want to use those as lighthouses and share the best practices that are going on.
And the universities can help with that.
We started a principal center in which we brought together a congress of principals, outstanding principals from all over the state.
We had 58 of them here last summer in what we call the Principal's Academy.
So we took House Bill 72 and said, how are we doing in implementing the Declaration of Independence?
Where are the problems now?
You know, performance appraisal was one.
How do we do good performance appraisal?
We actually set up some practices when we did that.
We brought in resource people to help with this.
The career ladder, we looked at that.
We brought in people who were the principals of the schools that Sarah Lightfoot wrote about in her study of high school.
The study showed some of the outstanding high schools in the country who brought the principals of some of those schools in.
We need to do more of that.
We need to share with each other what's the best ways to improve the quality of education.
in the schools.
Principals Academy, we can do, we set up nine clusters now around the state.
We're also tied in with other universities in those regions to help with those principals, 58 principals who attend the academy.
Those principals will come back in November for a follow-up meeting and come back next summer for another full week in the academy.
So we'll begin to have a network of practicing professionals
who can, in fact, be a part of a network for implementing good practices.
And they're all connected now with a hotline where we share information daily across these groups.
So there's a lot of good things going on in Texas.
There's a lot of interest on the part of the technology people who work with the state.
They're just setting up interactive TV programs.
They even pipe programs into schools
with a small roast because we only had a small group of students at an advanced level studying certain kinds of things.
You can connect several different schools.
You can make up a class.
And you can do this over interactive TV.
Or if they don't have a chemistry professor or a biology professor, you can pipe this in through interactive television.
Most programs are now in operation in Texas.
They're not extensively developed yet,
But they're on our way with us.

And I think we ought to highlight the good things that are going on, because as a result of a lot of the dialogue that took place with this black committee, the morale of the teachers, especially, got very low, because they interpreted the being in the focus, they interpreted it as criticism, especially when the Nation at Risk came out and said, you know, our schools are in a shambles, and that we were going to,
declare war or somebody was going to come in and try to defeat us, and they create schools like we've got now.
We're committing unilateral disarmament by the way we set up our education system.
Well, teachers can only take so much of that.
And really, even the good teachers feel like they're being beat on.
So if we can stop beating on the teachers and start emphasizing working together and helping at each of these levels,
I think that effort-wise, we're doing as much or more than almost any other state.
How does Texas rank with other states regarding public education?
Well, you see, I think you can't answer that question unless you take a specific area.
And the worst thing to do is to take
SAT tests and do comparisons like the federal government did, because as I mentioned before, you know, only 3% of the kids in North Dakota even take the test.
32% in Texas take it.
So comparing that data doesn't give you anything.
You know, what you really need to do is take an area, like with career ladders, there are nine states in the country that are experimenting with career ladders.
We're one of them.
Now, whether that makes us better than the other
41 states, they're not doing anything on that yet.
I don't know.
It all depends on whether Clean Water ends up being better than what existed before.
And we're in a state of piloting that, trying that.
I think it will be better.
I think it's better just because we're examining new ways to create a profession.
Trying ways to keep good teachers in the classrooms without having to become administrators in order to make a decent salary.
That's a good goal.
Now whether we can do it or not is yet to be seen.
But I'm proud to be in a state where we're trying.
Are very many other states reforming public education?
Quite a few of them.
Quite a few of them.
And they're doing it in different ways.
I don't know too many of them.
Perhaps New York and Tennessee.

uh moving in in florida and maybe north dakota i'm moving in in a very comprehensive way probably texas and there's a more all-encompassing set of reforms than any place else that i know of i mean what we're trying to do is deal with all the whole thing the curriculum the way schools are staffed the way they're evaluated the way they're administered we're trying to do

you know the way teachers are prepared the way they're evaluated we're dealing with everything in this reform package uh i can't think of any other state that has a more comprehensive reform package than texas it may be one of our problems you know because we're trying to do all of them at once
And we're trying to do it in a short period of time.
It's going to take some real sensitivity now to get, especially the teaching profession itself, involved in having some sense of ownership in this package, in implementing this package.
All of the surveys we've done so far indicate that the teachers are supportive of a lot of these reforms, like career ladders.
It's just that they have a lot of questions about the way they're being implemented and their lack of involvement in the design of them and the carrying out of them.
After this fact, did we get them to feel some investment in this whole thing and change those things?
We shouldn't be afraid to change those things that need changing because of the fact that it was such an all-encompassing bill
It would be very natural now to go back and have to fine tune it without destroying the major elements of it.
Do you have any personal ideas on other possible reforms for Texas that you would like to see implemented?
Well, I'd like to see a system where we have much more opportunity for school districts to innovate and try different approaches to the way schools are organized

I'd like to see a system where you have minimal options within the public education system, where you might have a school which is pretty much independently oriented, where your students do a lot of individual study and use a lot of technology.
You might have some schools organized around more than once a SORI approach.
You might have schools, some of them, run by industry in collaboration with the schools.
You have a lot more work in terms of
outside of the school activity and not have so much uniformity that doesn't allow a certain amount of uniformity in terms of goals and standards, I think you mean.
But the way those goals and standards are implemented, that we should have a lot of opportunity and flexibility and autonomy.
to meet those goals and standards.

I think the role of the state ought to be to set those goals and standards, but allow maximum freedom for the local communities in collaboration with community resources of a variety of kinds to find different ways of implementing these standards.
And I think that there are a lot of ways to use people in communities and resources that we haven't tapped yet.
I think that the way we conceive of education, we ought to be thinking of it more in terms of from birth throughout all of life.

People of all ages need education, and I can see us providing opportunities where you have some community education settings, where you have senior citizens, preschool children, children who are elementary and secondary,

in the same environments where you have the senior citizens leaving for the four-year-old and using schools as learning resource centers for anybody and open up the way we can see them in learning environments.
Okay.
And finally, what happened to Mr. and Mrs. Gabler?
Well, I think they're still around.
They attend the meetings each year when the textbooks are reviewed.
The thing that's different now at the textbook hearings than in the past is the people who are supportive of those texts also appear now.
Before, it only used to be those people who had some criticism of what was going on.
But at the hearings now, when the Gabriel speaks,
there's usually someone who will take the other side at that same textbook here who will, well, disagree.
But I think it's all silly.
Okay.
